title: Group 4
text:
Team members

Julia Hetzel
Luis Emilio
Nibin Zheng
Rachel Ruff

title: Group 4
text:
Phase 1: Data Cleaning and Preparation

# General Feedback:
# - The script is looking good in loading and processing the data!
# - Good naming of the variables!

# All good here!
library(gapminder)
library(tidyverse)

# All good here!
options(stringsAsFactors = FALSE) 
options(scipen = 999999)

# All good here!
folder_path = "C:/Users/jhetzel/Desktop/PAC/Workshop 1"
setwd(folder_path)

# All good here!
gdp <- read.csv("7-wb-gdp_per_capita.csv")
gov_expenditure <- read.csv("8-wb-gov_expenditure_education.csv", skip = 3)

# All good here!
cleangdp <- gdp %>%
  select(Country.Name, Country.Code, c(yr_1960 : yr_2005)) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(yr_1960 : yr_2005),
               names_to = "years",
               values_to = "total_gdp", 
               values_drop_na = TRUE) 

# All good here!
new_names <- as.character(gov_expenditure[1, ])
gov_expenditure <- gov_expenditure[-1, ]
colnames(gov_expenditure) <- new_names

# All good here!
clean_gov_expenditure <- gov_expenditure %>%
  select('Country Code', c('1960' : '2006')) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c('1960' : '2006'),
               names_to = "years",
               values_to = "expenditure", 
               values_drop_na = TRUE)

title: Group 3
text:
Team members

Amad Nadeem
Peter Beniaris
Sarah Zhao

title: Group 3
text:
Phase 1: Data Cleaning and Preparation

# General Feedback:
# - The script is very well-structured and looking good!

# All good here!
library(tidyverse)

# All good here!
mortality <- read_csv("raw-datasets/5-wb-mortality_rate_under5.csv")
electricty <- read_csv("raw-datasets/6-wb-access_eletricity.csv", skip = 4)

# All almost good here!
# Suggestion 1: breaking the lines for readability
mortality <- mortality %>% select(-country_name)

# Good use of the line breaker here and the : operator
new_mortality <- mortality %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = yr_1960:yr_2023,
    names_to = "Year",
    values_to = "Mortality"
  )

new_electricity <- electricty %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = `1960`:`2023`,
    names_to = "Year",
    values_to = "Percent"
  )

# All good here!
write_csv(new_mortality, "clean-datasets/clean_mortality.csv")
write_csv(new_electricity, "clean-datasets/clean_electricity.csv")

title: Group 2
text:
Team members

Alece Stancin
Catherine Arevalo
Rachel Blume

title: Group 2
text:
Phase 1: Data Cleaning and Preparation

# General Feedback:
# - The script is well-structured and shows a good grasp of data manipulation in R.
# - Make sure to use comments to explain why each step!
# - Make more use of the pipe operator to do more things in a sequence

# All good here! (good start!)
library(tidyverse)

# Normally, we can just run in the console the `getwd()` function! It's a one time run!
getwd()

# All good here! Good practice!
folder_path <- "C:/Users/alece/OneDrive/Documents/PAC/Data Workshop 1"
setwd(folder_path)

# All good here!
income <- read_csv("income.csv", skip = 4, col_names = TRUE)
poverty <- read_csv("poverty.csv")

# All good here!
glimpse(income)

# All almost good here!
# Suggestion 1: breaking the lines for readability
# Suggestion 2: keep the arguments separate by empty spaces
poverty_longer <- poverty %>%
  pivot_longer(cols=c(yr_1960:yr_2023), names_to= "Year", values_to="measurement")

# All good here!
glimpse(poverty)
glimpse(poverty_longer)

# Great cleaning!
poverty_longer <- poverty_longer %>%
  mutate(Year = str_remove(Year, "yr_"))
glimpse(poverty_longer)

# Great cleaning!
poverty_longer <- poverty_longer %>% 
  select(-"Indicator Name")

# Great cleaning!
poverty_longer <- poverty_longer %>% 
  mutate(Year = as.numeric(Year))

glimpse(poverty_longer)
glimpse(income)

# Almost all good!
# Issue: column's name (remember, R don't like empty spaces)
income <- income %>% mutate(`Country Code` = str_remove(`Country Code`, "ISO_"))
income <- income %>% select(-"...68")

# All almost good here!
# Suggestion 1: breaking the lines for readability
income_longer <- income %>% pivot_longer(cols=c(`1960`:`2023`), names_to = "Year", values_to= "measurement")

income_longer <- income_longer %>% select(-"Indicator Name")

income_longer <- income_longer %>% mutate(Year = as.numeric(Year))

# Writing cleaned and transformed data to CSV files, crucial for saving work and enabling further analysis.
write.csv(income_longer, "income_clean.csv")
write.csv(poverty_longer, "poverty_clean.csv")

title: Visualizations
section: Phase 3: Data Visualization and Presentation (group phase)
text: Phase 3: Data Visualization and Presentation (group phase)

title: Policy Analytics Credential
text:
What PAC is about?
Diving into a dataset and navigating the entire data analysis process can be a daunting task, particularly for newcomers to this field. The Policy Analytics Credential Program is designed by UChicago faculty and our experienced graduate instructors who serve as Teaching Fellows for UChicago master-level students. It starts at the beginner-friendly foundational level and equips you with a practical skillset in policy analysis using the UChicago approach within 9 weeks.

Features of the Program

Gain essential and practical skills in R programming and statistics Synchronous Policy
Insights & Data Exploration Workshops with UChicago Harris graduate instructors
Synchronous weekly teaching sessions
Join the UChicago Harris R user community
Shareable certification of completion to showcase your credential

title: Data Exploration Workshop
section: What are the Data Exploration Workshops?
text:
What are the Data Exploration Workshops?
The Data Workshop was designed to equip students with practical skills in handling real-world data, emphasizing teamwork, application of course concepts, and hands-on experience with data analysis tools in R. This workshop will guide students through a data analysis process from data cleaning to visualization, fostering both technical skills and collaborative problem-solving.


Structure of the Workshop

Phase 1: Data Cleaning and Preparation (group phase)
Phase 2: Data Integration and Initial Analysis (instructor review)
Phase 3: Data Visualization and Presentation (group phase)

title: Group 1
text:
Team members

Marcus Martinez
Raimundo Gana
Fatima Zehra

title: Group 1
text:
Phase 1: Data Cleaning and Preparation

# General Feedback:
# - Good use of tidyverse for data manipulation, which is powerful and expressive.
# - Consistent formatting in code makes it easier to read and maintain.
# - Consider commenting on each step of the script to explain why each operation is done, especially for beginners.
# - Introducing error checks (like checking for file existence before reading) could make the script more robust.

# All good here!
folder_path = "/Users/faelmassa/Desktop/Project Drac de Fusta/Harris PAC - AvrMai24/Policy Analytics Credential - UChicago Harris/Lectures/Week 3 - L10 - L14/Workshop 2/"
setwd(folder_path)

# Normally, we can just run in the console the `getwd()` function! It's a one time run!
getwd()

# All good here!
library(tidyverse)

# All good here!
slums <- read.csv("1-wb-slum_population.csv")
ruralpop <- read_csv("2-wb-rural_population.csv", skip = 4) 

# All good here!
glimpse(ruralpop)
colnames(ruralpop)

# Almost all good!
# Issue: column's name (remember, R don't like empty spaces)
ruralpop <- ruralpop %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = "1960":"2023",
               names_to = "Year",
               values_to = "Rural Pop (%)")

# All good here!
ruralpop <- ruralpop[, -4]

# Almost all good!
# Issue (same from above): column's name (remember, R don't like empty spaces)
ruralpop_3 <- ruralpop %>%
  mutate(`Country Code` = str_sub(`Country Code`, 5, 7))

# Same issue!
ruralpop_final <- ruralpop_3 %>%
  select(`Country Code`, `Indicator Code`, Year, `Rural Pop (%)`)

# All good here!
ruralpop_final <- ruralpop_final %>%
  mutate(Year = as.numeric(Year))
